intro: Achillea acuminata, commonly known as narrow-leaved yarrow, is a perennial herb native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its finely divided, gray-green leaves and flat-topped clusters of small white or pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and thrives in well-drained soils. It is often found in rocky or dry habitats and is valued for its ornamental appeal and historical use in traditional medicine. The genus Achillea is named after the legendary Greek hero Achilles, who supposedly used the plant to treat wounds.
